newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-SFE wheat falls on Chicago, pool price puzzle.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-SFE wheat falls on Chicago, pool price puzzle.

text.p: Wheat futures fell further on the Sydney Futures Exchange (SFE) on Monday after falls in Chicago and ahead of pool price revisions by the Australian Wheat Board.

Market leader January 1997 fell by A$2.00 to A$152.00 a tonne in 21 trades, while the contract lost A$1.50 on its settlement price. A total of 13 trades also took place in A$145.00 January 1997 put options at a A$4.80 premium.
Brendon Hillary of ANZ McCaughan Futures Ltd said it was surprising SFE wheat did not fall further. To fully reflect Chicago's Friday fall SFE wheat should have been down by A$3.00.

SFE wheat futures had not shared fully in Chicago's rally in the past fortnight. But Chicago was approaching a critical stage, where breaching of US$4.00 a bushel would indicate downside of a further $20.00-$30.00, he said.
The Australian pool estimate to be released this afternoon has the market guessing. A pool price on market criteria would indicate a cut of A$10.00-A$15.00 a tonne, he said.

But market rumours were that the AWB had decided not to reduce pool prices, perhaps because it believes world prices could tick upwards early next year or perhaps because of recent criticism about frequent pool price changes in a falling market.
The market would be comfortable with a A$10.00 pool price cut but a A$15.00 cut might bring selling pressure on, he said.
Monday's market attracted some good bids, particularly through BZW Futures, while nervous forward pricing prompted some grower selling.
The AWB's indicative cash wheat quotes, Newcastle delivery, were cut by A$2.00-A$3.00 a tonne on Monday morning.
